Situation (Use when): Engage users with browsing and searching options.
Intention (Why): Immediate user engagement and efficient navigation.
Implementation (How): Prominently display search, feature engaging content, and organize categories effectively.

Situation (Use when): Frequent content updates are essential, especially for news and social interaction platforms.
Intention (Why): Ensures fresh content, promotes user engagement, supports collaboration.
Implementation (How): Display items in reverse chronological order, offer personalization options, facilitate interaction, and adapt to mobile devices.

Situation (Use when): Presenting large collections of media or files.
Intention (Why): Provides intuitive browsing, selection, and management of items.
Implementation (How): Offer grid and single-item views, browsing interface with search, and customizable metadata options.

Situation (Use when): Users need quick access to key data and tasks.
Intention (Why): Provides concise, customizable overview of vital information.
Implementation (How): Identify user needs, prioritize data, use visual hierarchy and relevant patterns.

Situation (Use when): Users need to adjust preferences, settings, or properties.
Intention (Why): Provides easy access to manage application-wide or user-specific configurations.
Implementation (How): Organize settings into intuitive categories, follow platform conventions, use familiar layout patterns, and consider immediate application or save options.

Situation (Use when): Users have diverse preferences or need different perspectives on the same information.
Intention (Why): Accommodates varied usage scenarios and user preferences.
Implementation (How): Design specialized views, allow easy switching, preserve user state, and consider persistent preferences.

Situation (Use when): Users need to work on multiple tasks or compare different items simultaneously.
Intention (Why): Facilitates multitasking, supports side-by-side comparisons, enhances productivity.
Implementation (How): Use tabs, separate windows, panels, or split views to display multiple workspaces, allowing easy switching and customization.

Situation (Use when): Helping both new and experienced users with functionalities on the website and help with specific tasks.
Intention (Why): Users require varied support levels; comprehensive help ensures usability and accommodates different learning styles.
Implementation (How): Offer lightweight help, such as tooltips, and comprehensive guides accessible within the application or separately.

Situation (Use when): Employ tags to enable content classification, browsing, sharing, and user-generated organization, especially in large information repositories.
Intention (Why): Tags increase content relevance, user engagement, and platform retention. They also crowdsource organic content organization.
Implementation (How): Implement tagging systems for users to classify content, integrate tag-based search functionality, and format tags as clickable links.

Situation (Use when): Enhancing usability and brand recognition by mploying a visual framework for consistent layout and style across an app or site.
Intention (Why): Consistency in color, font, layout, and navigation aids improves user experience and promotes brand recognition.
Implementation (How): Define shared characteristics such as layout, color, and typography; implement through CSS, Java classes, or visual system libraries for easy maintenance and adjustment.

Situation (Use when): Utilize Center Stage for interfaces focused on a single task or coherent information, emphasizing clarity and user engagement.
Intention (Why): Directs user attention to primary content, reducing cognitive load and facilitating task completion.
Implementation (How): Establish a clear visual hierarchy with primary content dominating, positioning it prominently within the UI. Positioning can vary based on conventions but isn't strictly defined.

Situation (Use when): Present numerous similar content items, like articles or products, for easy comparison and selection.
Intention (Why): Establishes visual equality among items, aiding comparison and highlighting content semantics.
Implementation (How): Design a common item template, arrange in a grid, maintain visual consistency, and ensure responsiveness.

Situation (Use when): Organize abundant content into easily digestible sections for improved user scanning and comprehension.
Intention (Why): Enhances readability and comprehension by visually segmenting content into coherent thematic or task-based sections.
Implementation (How): Define sections with strong, concise titles; visually separate them and ensure coherence. If necessary, reorganize content for clarity.

Situation (Use when): Organize diverse content into coherent, tabbed modules, suitable for users who need to focus on one module at a time.
Intention (Why): Effectively declutters interfaces, enhances user focus, and facilitates content organization, particularly for static sets of related modules.
Implementation (How): Define coherent content chunks, assign short titles, indicate selected tabs clearly, and consider alternative tab placements for optimal usability.

Situation (Use when): Organize diverse content into collapsible panels for efficient display, ideal for interfaces with limited space.
Intention (Why): Enhances interface decluttering, enables easy content grouping, suitable for various interactive elements.
Implementation (How): Define concise section titles, incorporate visual affordances, allow multiple modules open concurrently, preserve state between sessions.

Situation (Use when): Organize supplementary content discretely for varied user needs, especially with heterogeneous or optional elements on the page.
Intention (Why): Simplifies interface, implements progressive disclosure, declutters content, accommodates user preferences.
Implementation (How): Encapsulate modules into panels with toggle controls, label accordingly, consider icons for clarity, use animations, adapt based on user behavior.

Situation (Use when): Designing for customizable interfaces, especially in desktop applications or sign-in websites with diverse user interests and activities.
Intention (Why): Enhances user efficiency, accommodates personal preferences, fosters engagement, supports future module integration.
Implementation (How): Name and size modules, allow drag-and-drop repositioning, enable open/close actions, offer removal and addition functionalities.

Situation (Use when): Displaying a list of items with associated content, enabling quick browsing and selection without overwhelming users.
Intention (Why): Established convention, facilitates efficient navigation, integrates list structure with item details seamlessly.
Implementation (How): Arrange two panels side by side, list on one, details on the other. Make selection obvious, support keyboard navigation.

Situation (Use when): Mobile apps or websites with constrained space, presenting a list and item details, ensuring shallow UI hierarchy.
Intention (Why): Maximizes available space, simplifies navigation, easy return to list view.
Implementation (How): Display list, replace with item details on selection, provide back button for navigation.

Situation (Use when): Displaying a vertically oriented list with associated item details, enabling easy comparison of multiple items.
Intention (Why): Shows item details within list context, allows simultaneous viewing of multiple items.
Implementation (How): Display list in column, open item details in place, use animated transitions for clarity.

Situation (Use when): Displaying heterogeneous items with consistent behaviors, adaptable to various screen sizes.
Intention (Why): Offers flexibility, familiarity, and consistency in presenting content across different devices.
Implementation (How): Design self-contained components with images, text, and actions; ensure readability and clarity across screen sizes.

Situation (Use when): Displaying small visual representations of items for quick scanning and selection in a grid layout.
Intention (Why): Provides a dense, visually appealing overview suitable for rapid item recognition and selection.
Implementation (How): Scale thumbnails uniformly, place metadata near them, process images for consistent presentation.

Situation (Use when): Displaying visually identifiable items for casual browsing in a limited space, encouraging engagement and serendipitous exploration.
Intention (Why): Engages users in visually inspecting items, offers compact browsing interface, encourages exploration, and provides focus plus context.
Implementation (How): Create thumbnails, arrange horizontally, add arrows for scrolling, consider enlarging central item, animate scrolling, offer scrollbar.

Situation (Use when): Displaying long lists, especially when loading entire list is impractical or slow, and users are likely to browse selectively.
Intention (Why): Breaks list into manageable chunks, empowers user control, common web convention, easy implementation.
Implementation (How): Determine items per page, design pagination controls, place at bottom or top for user convenience.

Situation (Use when): When users need to quickly select an item from a long list using keyboard input.
Intention (Why): Efficiently navigates long lists, reduces reliance on scrolling or clicking, enhances user experience.
Implementation (How): Automatically scrolls to match user input, selects matching item, supports incremental typing for rapid selection.

Situation (Use when): When users need to quickly navigate a long list alphabetically or numerically.
Intention (Why): Provides an interactive map for efficient navigation, akin to physical book tabs.
Implementation (How): Display letters/numbers on scroll bar, allow clicking to scroll to corresponding point in list.

Situation (Use when): In vertical interfaces with tables/lists, for efficient item creation without additional UI elements.
Intention (Why): Seamlessly integrates creation where items "live," enhancing coherence, elegance, and user efficiency.
Implementation (How): Enable easy initiation from empty row, edit columns for item setup, handle abandoned creations gracefully.

Situation (Use when): For organizing many related actions visibly on interfaces.
Intention (Why): Clarifies interface, groups actions logically, adheres to Gestalt principles, enhances user understanding, and simplifies navigation.
Implementation (How): Group related actions, use consistent graphic treatment, label appropriately, consider placement for visibility and hierarchy.

Situation (Use when): Many actions to show, preferring clean interface. Use Hover Tools for discoverability, keeping UI uncluttered yet accessible.
Intention (Why): Reveals actions on demand, maintains clean UI, enhances discoverability, and offers natural interaction.
Implementation (How): Hide actions until hovered, design with enough space, respond quickly, highlight hovered area if in list.

Situation (Use when): Many actions for items, not suitable for menus or pop-ups. Visibility, space, and freedom drive the choice.
Intention (Why): Enhanced visibility, space utilization, and freedom of presentation compared to menus or buttons.
Implementation (How): Allocate space, place near target, consider dynamic content, ensure easy access if closable.

Interaction Design Pattern: Prominent “Done” Button or Assumed Next Step
Situation (Use when): Finalizing transactions, confirming choices.
Intention (Why): Provides closure, guides users, enhances usability.
Implementation (How): Create prominent button, place logically, label clearly.

Situation (Use when): Contextual menu actions based on user selection.
Intention (Why): Enhances usability, reduces errors, promotes safe exploration.
Implementation (How): Dynamically update menu labels based on user context.

Situation (Use when): Before critical or complex actions, such as large file operations or online purchases, to prevent errors.
Intention (Why): Prevents mistakes, enhances user understanding, provides assurance.
Implementation (How): Display realistic previews of outcomes, offer options to proceed or modify.

Situation (Use when): During time-consuming operations, preventing user impatience and maintaining task focus.
Intention (Why): Indicates system activity, reduces user frustration, enhances patience.
Implementation (How): Display animated progress indicators, provide status updates, offer cancel options if applicable.

Situation (Use when): During time-consuming or modal operations, ensuring user control and freedom.
Intention (Why): Empowers users to halt or correct unintended or unwanted operations, supports safe exploration.
Implementation (How): Offer a prominent Cancel button, ensure immediate cancellation with feedback, clarify cancellation targets for parallel operations.

Situation (Use when): When accepting user input with unpredictable formats or styles, maintaining a visually simple interface.
Intention (Why): Simplifies user interaction by allowing flexible input, leveraging software to handle diverse inputs intelligently.
Implementation (How): Analyze potential inputs, program intelligently to interpret variations, and test extensively with real users for validation.

Situation (Use when): For requesting specific, well-defined text input with consistent formats like credit card numbers or local phone numbers.
Intention (Why): Provides clear input structure, reduces errors, and aids user understanding by breaking down data entry.
Implementation (How): Design structured text fields reflecting the format, automate focus shifting, and optionally provide input prompts for clarity.

Situation (Use when): For asking users to fill in one-line text, numbers, or choices when typical label/control pairs are unclear.
Intention (Why): Enhances interface clarity, simplifies rule construction, and aids user understanding with contextual sentences.
Implementation (How): Craft sentences carefully, place controls within text, align baselines, and consider localization challenges.

Situation (Use when): When a text field's required input isn't clear, and additional explanation beyond the label or text field is needed.
Intention (Why): Provides clarity, reduces user guesswork, and offers context without cluttering the label.
Implementation (How): Place short examples or sentences beside or below text fields, keeping hints concise and visually separated.

Situation (Use when): When default values aren't feasible, Input Prompts guide users on what to input, enhancing clarity.
Intention (Why): Enhances UI clarity, ensures user attention, differs from floating labels by focusing on user input.
Implementation (How): Place instructional text or examples within input fields, disable actions until input is provided.

Situation (Use when): Predictable inputs like URLs, names, or commands benefit from Autocompletion, enhancing efficiency and reducing errors.
Intention (Why): Saves time, reduces cognitive load, prevents errors, and enhances user experience, especially on mobile devices.
Implementation (How): Generate a list of possible completions as the user types, offer choices explicitly or automatically when there's only one logical completion.

Situation (Use when): For choices from sets, dates, or numbers, where space is limited but complex UI is necessary.
Intention (Why): Encapsulates complex UI in small space, maintains simplicity, and provides familiar interaction.
Implementation (How): Display current value with down arrow, clicking opens panel with choices; compact design, familiar formats.

Situation (Use when): Selecting items from a large source list to build a subset.
Intention (Why): Provides clarity by showing both lists together, improving scalability and user understanding.
Implementation (How): Display source and destination lists, use buttons or drag-and-drop for transfer, offer search and ordering functionalities.

Situation (Use when): Completing form-like inputs to save user time.
Intention (Why): Reduces user effort by providing reasonable default answers.
Implementation (How): Prefill fields with data from session, account, location, or time, ensuring user relevance and comfort.

Situation (Use when): Form input errors occur, such as skipped fields or invalid data.
Intention (Why): Helps users fix errors promptly, enhancing usability and preventing frustration.
Implementation (How): Display messages on the form itself, near the problematic fields, with clear instructions for correction.
